title: 113_s1415
content: The Act is titled the "Canyon Mountain Land Conveyance Act of 2013" and includes definitions for clarity. The Act titled the "Canyon Mountain Land Conveyance Act of 2013" defines "Federal land" as approximately 17,826 acres depicted on a specific map. It also defines "planning area" as land administered by the Bureau of Land Management in various districts and "public domain land" as defined in the Federal Land Policy and Management Act of 1976. The Act defines "public lands" as specified in the Federal Land Policy and Management Act of 1976. It excludes land managed under a specific 1937 Act. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of the Interior, and "Tribe" refers to the Cow Creek Band of Umpqua Tribe of Indians. SEC. 3. CONVEYANCE. The United States conveys all right, title, and interest in Federal land to the Tribe, held in trust for their benefit. A survey will establish the boundaries of the land taken into trust. SEC. 4. MAP AND LEGAL DESCRIPTION. SEC. 4. MAP AND LEGAL DESCRIPTION. The Secretary will file a map and legal description of Federal land with specified committees. The filed map and legal description will have the same force as the Act, with the Secretary allowed to correct errors. The information will be available for public inspection. SEC. 5. ADMINISTRATION. This Act does not affect existing Tribe rights to land. Prohibitions include restrictions on exporting unprocessed logs and prohibiting gaming activities on trust land. SEC. 6. FOREST MANAGEMENT. Commercial forestry on Federal land must comply with Federal laws. SEC. 7. LAND RECLASSIFICATION. The Secretary of Agriculture and the Secretary must identify Oregon and California Railroad land within 180 days. Public domain land of similar acreage and condition must be identified within 18 months. Maps depicting the identified land must be submitted to Congress within 2 years. The identified public domain land will be reclassified as land owned by the railroad after public comment. The Act of August 28, 1937 applies to land reclassified as owned by the Oregon and California Railroad.
